newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX crude breaks post-Gulf War high of $26.10.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX crude breaks post-Gulf War high of $26.10.

text.p: NYMEX crude broke its post-Gulf War high of $26.10 a barrel Wednesday afternoon after a spate of technical buying lifted crude out of lower levels late session.
January crude hit $26.15 a barrel minutes before the market's close at 1510 EST, and rose as high as $26.22 a barrel, up 51 cents.
"A lot of it was technical. There was good buying around $25.15, and it just started to go higher from there," said a dealer in New York.
In the morning, prompt crude failed to break $26.10, hit on October 22, sending it down to a session low of $25.03.
With the January contract in crude expiring Thursday, dealers said tomorrow's price action in crude will determine whether this was a genuine technical breakout.

"We'll see if traders view this price on a continuation basis or not, though the way the market has been behaving, it seems to want to," said William Brown, president of trading firm W.H. Brown. in New York.
"It blew right through $25.00 on Monday after sharp losses last week. It's ability to stay above the $25.00 area was significant (technically)," said Brown.
-- Harry Milling, New York Energy Desk, 212-859-1761
